newsitem.title: UK: IPE gas oil ends $1.25 weaker, Brent 23 cts adrift.
newsitem.headline: IPE gas oil ends $1.25 weaker, Brent 23 cts adrift.

text.p: IPE gas oil futures closed $1.25 a tonne lower on Tuesday as U.S. sellers brushed off the potentially bullish effect of snowstorms in the northeastern United States, brokers said.
April gas oil settled at $165.50 a tonne, 25 cents off the low, following a late burst of selling form the United States.
"The contract kept well away from yesterday's value area and built up good value at these lower levels," a broker said.
U.S. players were seen selling the contract down while European dealers appeared more supportive. Snowstorms in parts of the U.S. northeast failed to revive the contract.
It traded at around $166.50 a tonne for much of the day.
"The effect of the snow story was in the end to remind people what the time of year was rather than to show how cold it was," a broker said.
May Brent was 23 cents lower at $19.15 a barrel at 1704 GMT.

The contract spiked to the day's high of $19.27 a barrel around 1625 GMT, lifted by a break above $20.60 a barrel on May NYMEX crude. But May Brent was immediately sold into and retreated to trade in a range of $19.10 to $19.20 a barrel.
Heating oil was 0.18 cent higher on NYMEX at 54.60 cents a gallon.
Weekly U.S. inventory data was expected late on Tuesday and GNI said they expected crude, gasoline and distillate stocks all to be "flat to a couple of million barrels lower."
